abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Fair Game column notes BlackRock chairman Laurence D Fink could do more than just talk about ending practice of rewarding executives for short-termism--share buybacks and other short-term objectives which create immediate profit at expense of company’s long-term security; cites report indicating BlackRock voted to support this practice at companies 96.2 percent of time; investor Stephen Silberstein will present shareholder proposal at May annual meeting to address BlackRock’s dismal record on issue.

headline.print_headline: Wet Noodle Where a Stick Ought to Be
headline.main: BlackRock Wields Its Big Stick Like a Wet Noodle on C.E.O. Pay

snippet: The world’s largest investment manager has the power to change companies’ short-terms ways by voting to curb C.E.O. pay, but it rarely exercises it.
lead_paragraph: The world’s largest investment manager has the power to change companies’ short-terms ways by voting to curb C.E.O. pay, but it rarely exercises it.
